newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan Sunni leader among 12 killed by bomb.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan Sunni leader among 12 killed by bomb.

text.p: A bomb exploded outside a courthouse in the Pakistani city of Lahore on Saturday, killing at least 12 people, including the leader of a militant Sunni Moslem group, police and doctors said.

They said 68 others were wounded as the bomb, apparently left on a motorcycle, went off at about 12.30 p.m. (0730 GMT) when Sipah-i-Sahaba Pakistan (SSP) group leader Zia-ur-Rahman Faruqi and his deputy, Azam Tariq, arrived at the court.
Faruqi, SSP Patron-in-Chief, died in hospital while Tariq was seriously wounded, doctors said.
Eyewitnesses said most of the casualties were policemen, journalists, lawyers or SSP supporters who had gathered to scatter flowers over their leaders.
The two were due to appear before the Sessions Court in central Lahore, capital of Punjab province, on charges of involvement in sectarian killings of minority Shi'ite Moslems.
Shi'ites form about 15 percent of Pakistan's predominantly Sunni population of over 130 million but are the majority in neighbouring Iran.
The bomb appeared to be the latest move in a long-running feud between militant Sunnis and Shi'ites that cost more than 40 lives last year in Pakistan.

The secretary of Iran's National Security Council, Hassan Rowhani, urged the Pakistani government on Thursday to mount a "crackdown on terrorist groups in Pakistan and (prevent) the assassination of Shi'ite Moslems".
"The groups not only endanger Pakistan's security but also hamper the unity of Moslems," Rowhani, a Shi'ite cleric, told visiting Pakistani Foreign Minister Sahibzada Yaqoob Khan.
Shi'ite militancy in Pakistan was fuelled by the 1979 Islamic revolution in Iran, sparking a fierce backlash from well-armed Sunni groups such as the SSP.
Two Shi'ite leaders were killed in separate incidents in Pakistan on December 31 and a Shi'ite activist was shot dead on Monday.

Sunni-Shi'ite disputes over Islamic beliefs have often spilled into violence in Pakistan. There has been a wave of such incidents in recent months in Punjab and North West Frontier province in which many people have died.
